hints.content: The shape we see in the two-dimensional slice is an isosceles trapezoid. It is a trapezoid because it has two parallel sides and it is isosceles because its left side looks like the mirror image of the right side, like an isosceles triangle.
Which of the solids in the choices would produce a shape with sloping sides when sliced vertically?

The triangular, square, and pentagonal prisms all have vertical sides so slicing them vertically cannot produce a shape with sloping sides.

Note that we could make a *horizontal face* in the triangular and pentagonal prisms with a vertical slice, but this is not what the question asks.

Only a vertical slice through the pyramid produces a two-dimensional shape with sloping sides.

![pyramid with a square base](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/49b99cca0c4e580ceaef3d4fd5842ea463191ce8.png)

To produce an isosceles trapezoid, we can slice the pyramid making a vertical cut that does not pass through the center.

[pyramid with a square base, off-center cut
This is previous picture, which was unclear for many students reading hints.
https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5c4f5d18cffbd9888619838aea65c59f3f17f1d0.png]:

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/dbecfdce44a5aadc74d0a9ac88522b3b69cf48c4.png)

[Image created using Geogeobra software and used in accordance with their licensing terms, so long as KA continues to offer this material free of charge.]:

question.content:
A vertical slice through a three-dimensional solid produces a two-dimensional shape.

![isosceles trapezoid](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9a01e5fee86b7569b86f7e8f116595d328925a8c.png) 

**Which one of the following solids can produce this two-dimensional shape *as a vertical cross-section* when sliced vertically?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
Recall that a square has four sides of equal length and four right angles. 

When we plot home plate at $(15,15)$ and first base at $(-10,15)$, we can see that they are $25$ units apart: 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/44f0285f562f5c8fd1b180e1d4e9df7400ea2a68.png)

So this square has a side length of $25$. We need to create a square with four right angles and sides with length $25$ units.

When we plot all $4$ bases, we end up with a baseball diamond that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/320672c6b6e3dbe3441789c85dcada2d202948f8.png)

question.content:
A baseball diamond is in the shape of a square. There are $4$ bases: home plate, first base, second base, and third base. Each base is on a corner of the square. 

**Click on the graph below to draw a baseball diamond with home plate at $(15,15)$ and first base at $(-10,15)$.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Recall that a rectangle has two pairs of equal sides and four right angles.

 The TV screen is $40$ inches wide by $30$ inches high, so we should draw a rectangle with horizontal sides of $40$ units and vertical sides of $30$ units, starting at the point $(-20,15)$.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8390a82bf7fe4eecc59c6f238db42b96bcdac8ba.png)

When we plot all $4$ vertices of the TV screen, we end up with a drawing that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a5ed82257d423ca2217b51052f8f8d897e02ca4e.png)

question.content:
TV screen measurements refer to the diagonal distance across the screen, so a $50$-inch TV would not be $50$ inches wide or $50$ inches high. When Claudia measured her parents' new $50$-inch TV, she found that its screen was a rectangle $40$ inches wide by $30$ inches high.  

**Draw the TV screen in the coordinate plane with the upper-left corner at $(-20,15)$ and the longer sides parallel to the $x$-axis. ** 

 (The units of the graph are in inches.) 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Recall that a rectangle has two pairs of equal sides and four right angles. The soccer field is $45\,\text{m}$ wide by $90\,\text{m}$ long, so we should draw a rectangle with horizontal sides of $90$ units and vertical sides of $45$ units, starting at the point $(-45,35)$.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6b462f84c908b57f8482a6720b075cf5c54a960b.png)

When we plot all $4$ vertices of the soccer field, we end up with a drawing that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0d5a27b53ca6b850284d28c54cfdec9126432cd6.png)

question.content:
The minimum dimensions for a regulation $\,\text{FIFA}\,$ soccer field are $45\text{ m}$  wide by $90\,\text{m}$ long.  

**Draw a regulation soccer field with minimum dimensions in the coordinate plane with the upper-left corner at $(-45,35)$ so that the longer sides are parallel to the $x$-axis. ** 

 (The units of the graph are in meters.) 

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Recall that a rectangle has two pairs of equal sides and four right angles. The soccer field is $90\,\text{m}$  by $120\,\text{m}$, so we should draw a rectangle with horizontal sides of $120$ units and vertical sides of $90$ units, starting at the point $(-50,50)$.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d4bbe1ad9865e4302d7419fedb235942c795f300.png)

When we plot all $4$ vertices of the soccer field, we end up with a drawing that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/39fa9cb9a51658ce6dc4435887259feaeb249a62.png)

question.content:
The maximum dimensions for a regulation $\,\text{FIFA}\,$ soccer field are $90\,\text{m}$ by $120\,\text{m}$.  

**Draw a soccer field with maximum dimensions in the coordinate plane with the upper-left corner at $(-50,50)$ so that the longer sides are parallel to the $x$-axis. ** 

 (The units of the graph are in meters.) 



[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]
